div.head:
Embleme 39. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Œdipus having overcome Sphynx, and Killd his father Laius,
marryed his Mother Jocasta.

lg.l: Sphynx with her riddles did the Thebans dread,
But subtill Œdipus her wiles betraydbetrayed:
The quæstion was, who in the morning might
Have four feet, two at noon, and three at night.
Unknowne his father hee deprives of life
And his owne mother takes to be his wife

div.head: Discourse 39.
div.ab:
Bacasser a Philosopher in Turba sayth, that which you seeke for is of noe small
value, for you seeke the greatest treasure, and most excellent gift of God.-
And learne, O yeeye students, that which the Philosophers have long since inti
mated, saying, The truth is not discerned but by errour, and nothing begets-
more greife to the heart, than errour in this art and worke: For when a man
thinks hee hath done, hath a world, hee will find nothing in his-
hands. these same things the ancient Philosophers were pleasdpleased
to signify, propounding a Sphynx as if shee denoted the obscu
rity and meanders of art. For this reason the Ægyptians, in their
sacred Isiaci, which were celebrattedcelebrated in honour of Osiris, by mitred
Preists, with heads shaven, and all parts of the body cloathed with
a white linnen garment downe to the ankles, that they might not
be knowne or discovered to the coḿon people, erected a Statue of
Silence, which was called Sigalion, in the entrance of the alter,-
the assistants being enjoyned to keep silence, and turne their-
eyes to that image, and for the same cause they added the effi
gies of Sphynxes at the corners of the altar, which did represent
the mysticall knowledge of sacred things; as Boissardus doth from
ancient Authors demonstrate: For Sphynx is a certaine kind of Mon
ster most obscure to the Thebans, propounding riddles, nor onely to-
them, but as before to the Ægyptians, soe after all others to those that-
aspire to art, and watchethwatches in the Philosophers books as before the gates of
Thebes; if any man can passe by the monster, hee suffers noe evill by
him, but hee that through præsumptionpresumption of mind or witt endeavours to-
resolve his riddles, and cannot performe, acquires his owne destruction,-
that is, greife to the heart, and damage to his affaires by errour in this-
worke. Hee that referrs such allegoryes to history, hath a MushromeMushroom for-
a head, and a Millon for a heart, as the ComædianComedian sayth, and knowes noe
more than that hee deviates from the right way. Those things are too
childish, and fitt for old wives, if they be taken literally, otherwise the
signs and tokens of profound learning. Monstrous wild beasts are indeed
sayd to be in Africa by the name of Sphynxes, but here wee discourse not
of them, though the originall and denomination of this fiction seems to-
be derived from them. The Philosophers Sphynx understands and-
usethuses humane speech, namely greekegreek, as allso propoundespropounds Subtill sen
tences and æmigmaticallenigmatical quæstions, in which appears a singular Sharp
nesseSharpness of understanding and learning, not soe obvious to all other men,
from which brutes are exceding distant. Hee that is conversant in-
the Philosophers assertions will easily know them to be such: For-
where one thing is sayd, and another thing signifyd, there æqui
vocationequivocation begettsbegets errour, which is not onely permitted, but allso enjoyned

to the Philosophers alone: The City of Thebes therefore being long-
perplexed with the riddles of Sphynx at length came one Œdipus,-
who gave such responses to the quæstions offered, that Sphynx could
not forbear throwing herselfe downe from a rocke. But who is this-
Œdipus? The Sonne of the King of Thebes, who being borne, it be
ing prædictedpredicted to his father by an oracle, that hee should be Slayne
by his Sonne, hee coḿanded Œdipus to be killd, who being hangdhanged-
upon a tree and left with a rope fastened crosse his feet, was relea
sed by another country-man, and brought up; Hee coming to mans
estate had indeed swelldswelled feet, but sufficiently declared a quicke-
witt above all men in unriddling this ænigmaenigma propounded by Sphynx.
But Sphinx is reported to have had many riddles, though this the cheife,
offered to Œdipus. What is that which in the morning goethgoes upon foure
feet, at noonenoon upon two, in the evening upon three? what was answerd
by Œdipus is not knowne; but some interpret it to the age of man, who
are deceived: For a Quadrangle or the four Elements of all things are
first to be considered, from hence wee come to the hemisphere having
two lines one streightstraight the other crooked, that is, while Luna, from hence
to a Triangle, which consists of body, Spirit, and Soule, or Sol, Luna,
and Mercury: Hereupon sayth Rhasis in his Epistle. The Stone is a Tri
angle in being, a Quadrangle in quality. Hereto allso relates the one
and twentyethtwentieth embleme, and the exposition thereof. Œdipus moreover
is notorious for parricide and incest, which are two the most detestable-
vices, as can ever be thought of, but neverthelesse they promoted him to a
kingdome, otherwise due to him, hee having unawares killed his father-
refusing to give way to him, and marryed the Queen, the wife of Laius,
his owne mother. But this written not to be imitated by any man as
history, or example, it being onely feigned and allegorically intro
duced by the Philosophers to discover the secrets of their doctrine. For
in this worke both happen; the first efficient, that is, the father, being
killd and destroyed by his effect, that is, the Sonne, and afterwards-
the same effect joynd the second efficient to himselfe, till shee be
come one with him, and soe the Sonne is coupled to his mother by-
matrimony, and enjoyes his fathers kingdome, as it were by a triple-
right, of armesarms, wedlockewedlock, and succession. Hee hath swelldswelled feet, because
hee cannot runne, and is as a bear, as hee containes the greatest se
cret, or a toad, going with a slow pace; because it is fixed fixing-
another, and not avoyding or fearing fire, which though a medium
of mean repute the Philosophers can by noe means be without. .
